intro: Erysimum insulare subsp. suffrutescens, commonly known as the island wallflower, is a perennial herb native to the Canary Islands. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring erect, branched stems covered in fine, hairy hairs. The plant produces clusters of bright yellow, four-petaled flowers that bloom in spring and early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped, slightly hairy, and arranged alternately along the stem. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or coastal habitats.
